description: Borrowed from German Phylogenie, coined by Ernst Haeckel in 1866, a neologism created as if borrowed from a Classic Greek word φυλογένεια (phulogéneia), composed from Ancient Greek φῦλον (phûlon, “tribe, genus, species”) + Ancient Greek -γένεια (-géneia, “-geny (generation, production)”).

entries.meaning: (systematics) The evolutionary history of groups of organisms, such as species or clades.
The historical development of a human social or racial group.
examples: Understanding the phylogeny of this musical group helps us understand its music.

entries.meaning: The historical development of any thing, idea, etc.
